DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US government spokesperson said the first China trade deal would include a tariff roll back, while China MOFCOM also stated that China and US have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases and that negotiators are still trying to reach an interim deal. MOFCOM added that the magnitude of tariff cancellations for Phase 1 deal can be negotiated and that if a Phase 1 trade deal is reached, both sides must cancel tariffs at the same time with the proportion based on agreement. (Newswires/SCMP)

US is said to still be targeting next week as a timeline to sign on a phase 1 deal according to CNBC's Tausche, while FBN's Lawrence also stated that US and China trade sources from both sides say they are still negotiating using the APEC timeframe and that both want to have a Phase 1 deal down on paper by the end of next week. (Twitter)

There were later reports that the US plan to roll back China tariffs faces fierce internal opposition where no final decision has yet been made, while other sources stated that China wants all tariffs rolled back as phases of the trade deals are completed and that the US offered to roll back some tariffs but want to keep majority in place until the Chinese reach certain milestones after the full trade deal is completed. Furthermore, NEC Director Kudlow commented there will be tariff concessions if there is a Phase 1 deal. (Newswires/Fox/Twitter)

China's Global Times Editor Hu Xijin said that the attitude of the Chinese side is clear that the two sides must simultaneously and proportionally remove the existing additional tariffs in order to reach phase 1 deal. Furthermore, Hu added that this is a realistic way to de-escalate the trade war and hopes it is also attitude of the US side. (Twitter)

China's Global Times tweeted China will accelerate the opening-up of the financial industry, lift all restrictions from the scope of business for foreign banks, securities firms and fund management firms. (Newswires)

China are considering the removal of restrictions on poultry imports for the US, according to Chinese press. (Xinhua)

 

UK/EU

BoE MPC voted 7-2 (Exp. 9-0) in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% in which Haskel and Saunders voted in favour of a 25bps cut, while it voted 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln as well as to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln.

BoE stated monetary policy could respond in either direction to changes in the economic outlook in order to ensure a sustainable return of inflation to the 2% target. If global growth fails to stabilise or Brexit uncertainties remain entrenched, monetary policy may need to reinforce the expected recovery in UK GDP growth and inflation. If these risks do not materialise and the economy recovers broadly in line with the MPC’s projections, monetary policy could be tightened at a gradual pace and to a limited extent. Furthermore, the MPC removed guidance on the event of a no-deal Brexit and stated that as a result of the UK and EU striking a deal on the WA and Political declaration and extension to A50, the perceived likelihood of a no deal Brexit has fallen markedly.

BoE Governor Carney said the world risks slipping into low growth and low inflation rut, while he also suggested that global growth is well below trend and is close to where we move to something that begins to feel like a recession. However, he also suggested that recent Brexit deal creates possibility of pickup in UK growth and that the pace of recovery depends critically on how much Brexit uncertainty dissipates.

BoE Governor Carney said pickup-up in UK growth likely to be limited by a lack of supply capacity in the economy and that if downside risks emerge to UK economy, there may be a need to provide reinforcement but this is not pre-committing, while he reiterated the MPC has considerable policy flexibility and ammunition.

  • CPI Inflation: 2019 Q4: 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%), 2020 Q4: 1.5% (Prev. 1.8%), 2021 Q4: 2.0% (Prev. 1.9%), 2022 Q4: 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%)
  • GDP Growth: 2019 Q4: 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%), 2020 Q4: 1.6% (Prev. 1.5%), 2021 Q4 1.8% (Prev. 2.2%), 2022 Q4 2.1% (Prev. 2.3%)

MARKET RECAP

US equity markets saw new ATHs from the get-go after it was reported both the US and China were to remove existing tariffs as part of their trade deal, although later reports of internal US opposition and caveats to such measures saw some paring. However, the risk appetite was evident, with higher oil prices boosting the energy sector, higher Treasury yields boosting the financials, and cyclical sectors, such as tech and telecoms, leading the pact too; defensives (health care and utilities) were predictably subdued. Havens in general took hits, with XAU shedding over 20 bucks, with an ounce of bullion now closer to 1,450 than it is 1,500, and UsdJpy drifting further above its 200dma at 109.02, which has served as resistance in recent sessions. HP Inc. (HPQ) confirmed Xerox’s (XRX) proposal, and CNBC’s Faber noted XRX reportedly offered HPQ USD 22/share in its takeover offer, citing sources. Beyond Meat (BYND) saw positive moves during hours as it announced it is looking to enter Asia before the year end. In broker moves, Mylan (MYL) was downgraded at Morgan Stanley to Equalweight from Overweight and Twitter (TWTR) was downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Evercore. American Outdoor Brands (AOBC) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) rallied in afternoon trade as the US reportedly ruled easing firearm exports, passing a key procedural milestone with the exports potentially being put in place by the end of 2019, according to sources. Altria (MO) shares were offered on reports JUUL was to stop the sale of mint-flavoured vaping products in the US, a key revenue stream for the regulatory burdened Co. S&P 500 0.3% at 3085, NASDAQ-100 0.3% at 8220, Dow Jones 0.7% at 27675.

The TPLEX continued its march lower on Thursday, following some reprieve on Wednesday, as reports confirmed the US and China were moving to both remove tariffs on each other. The US sold 19bln in 30-year bonds tailing the 2.424% WI by 0.6bps, whilst being covered by 2.23x, in line with the six-auction average; the takedown was impressive, however, with dealers taking a record low share of 20.7%, directs took an impressive 20.5%, whilst indirects took 58.8%, in line with their average. However, although an impressive 30-year auction, it did little to change the dial on the sell-off in the debt complex. By settlement the US Treasury curve had re-steepened from Wednesday, with the 2s/10s just over 3bps wider, with the 2-year yield just over 7bps higher itself. T-note futures (Z9) settled 30 ticks lower at 128-12+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 7th November 2019: Investors flock to risk on reports of tariff rollbacks, before paring back
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 7th November 2019: Investors flock to risk on reports of tariff rollbacks, before paring back

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up

* REAR VIEW: US & China agree to scale back tariffs in phases, although internal US opposition; BoE leave rates unchanged, but two members voted for a cut; solid 30-year auction

* COMING-UP: Data: German Imports, Exports, Trade Balance; Canadian Labour Market Report; University of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes Rig Count; Chinese Exports, Imports and Trade Balance. Speakers: Fed’s Bostic, Williams, Daly, Brainard. Events: RBA Statement on Monetary Policy, Moody’s Reviewing the UK’s Sovereign Debt Rating. Earnings: Duke Energy, Allianz, Intesa Sanpaolo, Credit Agricole, Richemont.

 

* MARKETS WRAP: US equity markets saw new ATHs from the get-go after it was reported both the US and China were to remove existing tariffs as part of their trade deal, although later reports of internal US opposition and caveats to such measures saw some paring. However, the risk appetite was evident, with higher oil prices boosting the energy sector, higher Treasury yields boosting the financials, and cyclical sectors, such as tech and telecoms, leading the pact too; defensives (health care and utilities) were predictably subdued. Havens in general took hits, with XAU shedding over 20 bucks, with an ounce of bullion now closer to 1,450 than it is 1,500, and UsdJpy drifting further above its 200dma at 109.02, which has served as resistance in recent sessions. The US sold USD 19bln of 30-year bonds in what was an impressive auction, but still, the risk-on sentiment very much overpowered any meaningful turn around in the debt complex’s sell-off. The higher yields were dollar supportive, but so too was the BoE meeting, which caught cable longs offside after the decision to hold was diluted by two dovish dissenters, opening up the potential for easing from the bank as global growth concerns and Brexit uncertainty linger into UK monpol.

* US/CHINA TRADE: A further bout of optimistic US/China headlines hit the market this morning, where both sides agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, noting the magnitude of cancellations can be negotiated and will depend on the phase one content. However, optimism was faded somewhat on sources reports from Reuters that there was “fierce” opposition within the White House on the plans to roll back the tariffs, with no decision yet been made, with a separate WSJ piece citing a US source as saying there had been no plans to roll back tariffs; this caution does align with some previous reports, such as the FT which suggested it was unclear whether Trump would agree, and previous hawkish sentiment from White House Trade Advisor Navarro, who said a few weeks ago he would be opposed to tariff roll backs until progress on IP theft had been made. However, close to the US cash equity close NEC Director Kudlow said there would be tariff concessions if there was a Phase One deal (he didn’t clarify whether or not if concessions will be removed on the actual signing of the deal, nor how much of the tariffs would be rolled back to). FBN’s Lawrence reported China trade sources saying that China wants all tariffs rolled back as phases of the trade deal are completed, and that the US offered to roll back some tariffs but wants to keep majority in place until the Chinese reach certain milestones after the full trade deal is completed. Additionally, the Chinese have recently been very vocal in questioning whether a phase one deal could be signed, unless the US issued a complete removal of tariffs, which had been a key sticking point in talks. Earlier on, China Global times Editor noted the attitude of the Chinese side is clear that both sides must simultaneously and proportionally remove existing additional tariffs in order to reach a phase one deal, seeming more in line with China’s recent requests. China’s MOFCOM stated if a phase one deal is reached, both sides must cancel the agreed scale of tariffs simultaneously. The “if” used in the language suggest a deal is not certain, but nonetheless, progress is clearly still being made. At midday, the US announced that the first trade deal with China would include a rollback of tariffs, further adding to the risk on sentiment. All-in-all, none of the back-and-forth headlines and sources reports seem to contain details that cover timing, implementation and precise timing of tariff roll backs, details which will surely become clearer as the sides move closer to an agreement, or not. Separately, on fentanyl imports, the Chinese Narcotic Commission sentenced nine people for smuggling fentanyl into the US, in accordance with a consensus reached by US President Trump and Chinese President Xi. Trump has constantly advocated for the Chinese to help more with the fentanyl shipments with the US, therefore this move will likely be praised by the President.

* BOE: Policymakers at the MPC once again opted to stand pat on rates at 0.75%, however, this time around the decision was subject to dissent from Haskel and Saunders who, instead favoured a 25bps rate reduction (consensus looked for a unanimous decision). Haskel and Saunders opted to dissent on the basis that downside risks to the Bank’s projections have emanated from a softer global outlook and more persistent Brexit uncertainties affecting corporate and household spending. However, this stance was out-voted by the broader view that there is currently not enough data points available to assess the impact of the aforementioned concerns held by those wishing for a rate reduction. Elsewhere, one key aspect of the minutes release was the Bank’s updated view on Brexit which underpinned the accompanying projections in the MPR. Policymakers noted that as a result of the UK and EU striking a deal on the WA, Political declaration and extension to A50, the perceived likelihood of a no deal Brexit has fallen markedly. As such, the MPC now assume an orderly transition to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. With this in mind, the MPC opted to remove guidance on what action would be taken in the event of a no deal Brexit, whilst reiterating their mantra to respond in either direction to ensure “a sustainable return of inflation to the 2% target”. Furthermore, the Bank reassured markets once again that a period of “entrenched uncertainty” could be a cause to act, however, if these risks do not materialise and the economy recovers broadly in line with the MPC’s projections, “monetary policy could be tightened at a gradual pace and to a limited extent”. Overall, the latest communication from the Bank suggests less concern over the possibility of a no deal Brexit, however, a further prolongation of the Brexit process could see the BoE provide the UK economy with further monetary loosening. Piecing it all together, the dissent to the decision suggests that the MPC has moved further away from its previous bias of gradual and limited rate rises, however, the Bank feels confident in using PM Johnson’s deal as a basis for their forward-looking assumptions and therefore appear to have greater conviction in their outlook than in previous reports. That said, given the upcoming general election, whether or not this deal will materialise is yet to be seen and therefore by the time of the next MPR in January (on day before the current A50 extension deadline), it is plausible another Brexit outcome could have to be factored in. Overall, ING suggest “while we expect 2020 to be another uncertain year for the UK economy, we still think it is probably still a little too early to be pencilling in rate cuts”.

* GEOPOLITICS: Iran continues to scale back its commitments to the 2015 nuclear accord, where Arab News reported this morning the uranium enrichment level at the Fordow plant is almost at pre-nuclear levels, also of note, a UN nuclear inspector has had her accreditation removed by Iran, reported AFP. Over in Korea, the South is working with the US to undertake joint air exercises at a reduced scope this month, as scheduled, in spite of complaints from North Korea, who called the acts extremely provocative and a dangerous act, adding dialogue with the US is on the verge of extinction.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.80 HIGHER AT USD 57.15/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLED USD 0.55 HIGHER AT USD 62.29/BBL. Crude markets mostly recovered from Wednesday’s bearish EIA Inventory report led sell off, as positive US/China trade developments lifted market sentiment. WTI Dec’ 19 futures briefly managed to eclipse yesterday’s USD 57.83/bbl high. Meanwhile, Brent Jan’ 20 futures, although making solid gains, failed to break back above the USD 63.00/bbl mark and threaten yesterday’s USD 63.30/bbl high. Crude specific newsflow on the day has been very light; Motiva Port Arthur Texas Refinery (636k BPD) has reportedly shut its reformer and hydrotreaters, sources stated. Elsewhere, regarding Saudi Aramco; the Co. signed five 2020 crude oil supply contracts at China's largest trade fair, which will increase the Co.’s total volume by 151k BPD compared to 2019 supply contracts, said the company in a statement. The acting CEO of South Africa's Central Energy Fund said plans regarding a 300k BPD refinery in partnership with Saudi Aramco, are progressing well and the refinery is expected to come by 2028.

* T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 30 TICKS LOWER AT 128-12+. The TPLEX continued its march lower on Thursday, following some reprieve on Wednesday, as reports confirmed the US and China were moving to both remove tariffs on each other. The US sold 19bln in 30-year bonds tailing the 2.424% WI by 0.6bps, whilst being covered by 2.23x, in line with the six-auction average; the takedown was impressive, however, with dealers taking a record low share of 20.7%, directs took an impressive 20.5%, whilst indirects took 58.8%, in line with their average. However, although an impressive 30-year auction, it did little to change the dial on the sell-off in the debt complex. By settlement the US Treasury curve had re-steepened from Wednesday, with the 2s/10s just over 3bps wider, with the 2-year yield just over 7bps higher itself.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.3% at 3085, NASDAQ-100 0.3% at 8220, Dow Jones 0.7% at 27675.

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.6%, Consumer Staples -0.4%, Energy 1.6%, Financials 0.7%, Health Care 0.1%, Industrials 0.2%, Information Technology 0.7%, Materials 0.7%, Telecommunication Services 0.7%, Utilities -1.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: HP Inc. (HPQ) confirmed Xerox’s (XRX) proposal, and CNBC’s Faber noted XRX reportedly offered HPQ USD 22/share in its takeover offer, citing sources. Beyond Meat (BYND) saw positive moves during hours as it announced it is looking to enter Asia before the year end. In broker moves, Mylan (MYL) was downgraded at Morgan Stanley to Equalweight from Overweight and Twitter (TWTR) was downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Evercore. American Outdoor Brands (AOBC) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) rallied in afternoon trade as the US reportedly ruled easing firearm exports, passing a key procedural milestone with the exports potentially being put in place by the end of 2019, according to sources. Altria (MO) shares were offered on reports JUUL was to stop the sale of mint-flavoured vaping products in the US, a key revenue stream for regulatory burdened co.

* EARNINGS: Ralph Lauren (RL) led the SPX gainers on Thursday after EPS, SSS and revenue beats. Century Link (CTL) also among SPX leaders after strong earnings. Fox (FOXA) also in the green today following positive earnings where it announced a USD 2bln share repurchase programme, with USD 500mln to commence immediately. Baidu (BIDU) traded higher after EPS beat expectations, revenue fell in line, and announced a 25% Y/Y increase in DAUs. Qualcomm QCOM) higher on EPS and revenue beats whilst also providing decent guidance for Q4. Travel names TripAdviser (TRIP) and Expedia (EXPE) lower on EPS and revenue misses, with the latter cutting its FY19 adj. EBITDA forecast, weighing on competitor Booking Holdings (BKNG), which is expected to report after the bell on Thursday. Nielsen (NLSN) traded higher in the pre-market before reversing course on the open amid the conclusion of its strategic review where it is to spin off its Global Connect business, although Street Insider reported it had offers for both parts of its business. Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) traded in the red today after its earnings where it announced it expects a further USD 2bln impairment charge in relation to the California fires from 2017 and 2018. Roku (ROKU) tumbled after posting a larger loss than expected, putting a break on its impressive rally.

* FX WRAP: DXY traded firmer today breaching 98.00 to the upside as yields continued to rise throughout the session on the initial positive US/China headlines which triggered safe haven outflows for the majority of the session, although towards the tail-end it was reported there was fierce internal opposition in the US on rolling back tariffs in the first deal. GBP traded weaker today as the BoE left rates unchanged at 0.75% as expected, although there were two surprise dovish dissenters who opted for a cut. EUR traded weaker against the buck amid broad dollar strength, although German industrial output declined 0.6%, missing expectations for a 0.4% fall. Havens lower today on the initial positive reports, although downside was limited following negative source reports from the US. USDJPY however remained above the 109-handle heading into Asia trade, from lows of 108.66. XAU traded as low as 1461 on the continued positive trade updates, however the precious metal caught a slight bid on the US source reports, albeit only slightly as it heads into Asia-Pac around the ~1470 mark. CHF traded lower against the greenback, but flat against EUR & GBP. In EMFX, the regular constituents mainly traded on risk appetite, however, BRL continued to weaken today despite the economy ministry raising its GDP growth forecasts, although it cut its CPI forecasts to 3.3% from 3.6% for 2019. Brazil’s Inflation data this morning was in line with expectations, but Y/Y fell from the prior and M/M ticked up to 0.1% from -0.4%. MXN traded flat against the buck after printing very much in line inflation expectations, but its M/M metric picked up to 0.54% from the prior 0.26%. ZAR was firmer against the buck despite poor manufacturing production data, and a fall in business confidence, and reports of loadshedding tonight and a high risk of loadshedding tomorrow at the state-owned Eskom.

subject: ANALYSIS: Spanish elections forecast to fail in breaking political deadlock
content:
* POLLS: On Sunday November 10th, Spaniards will return to the polls for the second time this year, after acting PM Sanchez (Leader of Spanish Socialist Workers Party, PSOE) failed to form a coalition government following April’s inconclusive elections. Yet polling in the run up to next election points towards the outcome being even less conclusive than the last; El Pais polling (October 23rd-29th) sees PSOE maintain its status as the country’s largest party, taking a 27.3% share of the vote, which would see the party gain 121 seats, two less than the 123 seats it currently holds; and significantly below the 176 required for an absolute majority. Meanwhile, the left-wing Unidas Podemos Party, who failed to form a coalition government with PSOE despite extensive negotiations, look set to lose roughly 2% of the popular vote which would see the Party’s number of seats fall to 31 from 42. Some of the votes lost by these two parties looks set to go to the newly formed centre left party Mas Pais, who formed out of protest against PSOE and Unidas Podemos’ failure to form a coalition government. The left-wing also appear to have relinquished some support to the right-wing People’s Party and Vox, who have seen their popularity rise amid unrest in Catalunya due to their tough stance against Catalan independence. They look set to gain 4.5% and 3.5% of the vote respectively, translating into a 25-seat gain for People’s Party and a 22-seat gain for Vox. However, much of this gain does come as a result a substantial fall in support for centre right party Ciudadanos (Citizens), who are slated to lose 43 seats. Other recent polls point to a similar result in terms of no party achieving a majority.

* DEADLOCK TO CONTINUE: Despite some shuffling of seats, the underlying picture looks set to be little changed, as in, neither the left-wing parties or the right parties look likely to gain enough support to form a coalition with a convincing majority. In that regard, political uncertainty looks set to continue, as parties’ manoeuvre to form a functional coalition.

* EFFECT ON SPAIN’S ECONOMY: “The economic impact of further political stalemate is likely to be negligible” argues CapEco, citing the fact that recent previous elections and the Catalonia independence referendum in 2017 did little to dent activity or confidence in Spain. Which would imply that, as long as things go as expected (i.e. deadlock continues), Spain's election is likely to be a market non-event. However, the consultancy argues that Spain’s economy, which has outperformed the Eurozone in recent years, is likely to slow down over the next year or so for non-political reasons; firstly, consumer spending growth is set to slow down now that the countries period of rapid employment growth appears to have ended. Secondly, investment is likely to grow at a slower pace than in the past couple of years due to recent declines in business confidence, recent drops in the country’s Manufacturing PMI data and a drop in Spanish firms’ demand for credit to fund fixed investment, which fell sharply in Q3. Finally, with government debt levels near 100% of GDP and a structural budget deficit of 2.6%, hopes of a big fiscal stimulus are likely to be dashed. “We expect GDP growth to slow from 2.0% this year to 1.2% in 2020”, concludes CapEco.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: not so super Thursday for Sterling, but fab for Norwegian Crown and Yuan
content:
NOK/GBP

Flanking the G10 ranks amidst a broad recovery in risk sentiment sparked by China’s Commerce Ministry claiming that the US has agreed to a phased and concurrent removal of like-for-like tariffs based on content and contingent on finalising trade deal Phase 1. Norway’s Krona is flying with extra impetus from manufacturing production rising twice as much as expected and a firm rebound in crude prices, plus increasingly bullish technical impulses. Indeed, Eur/Nok breached Fib support at 10.0610 after clearing the 1.1300-1.12500 area that held earlier in the week to expose a deeper downside chart target at 10.0350 (50 DMA) and 10.0000 vs a 10.3100+ record high set on October 29. Conversely, the Pound has been undermined by 2 dovish dissenters at the BoE’s MPC, including erstwhile hawk Saunders who teamed up with Haskel in favour of a pre-emptive 25 bp rate cut. Cable had already slipped below the 10 DMA (1.2881) and tested the 21 DMA (1.2839), but then ducked under 1.2800 and stopped just short of a recent trough (1.2789 from late last month) before paring some lost ground. Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp bounced from near 0.8600 lows through the 21 DMA (0.8646) and 0.8650 before the cross topped out. Back to the BoE, MPR and latest minutes, the dissent to the decision suggests that the MPC has moved further away from its previous bias of gradual and limited rate rises, but the Bank feels confident using PM Johnson’s Brexit deal as a basis for its forward-looking assumptions and therefore appears to have greater conviction in the outlook than in previous reports. That said, given the upcoming general election, whether or not this deal will materialise is yet to be seen and therefore by the time of the next MPR in January (one day before the current A50 extension deadline), it is plausible that another Brexit outcome could have to be factored in. 

CNH/AUD

Although the Greenback gradually derived momentum from a sharp rebound in US Treasury yields and reversion to marked curve steepening, with the DXY finally eclipsing Fib resistance at 98.085, the offshore Yuan maintained gains and got close to 6.9625 multi-month highs. To recap, Usd/Cnh (and Usd/Cny) retreated below 7.0000 on the aforementioned positive US-China trade reports that were subsequently embellished by media talk suggesting that Washington is still eyeing next week for Trump and X1 to seal Phase 1, contrary to speculation on Wednesday that the ceremonious signing between the 2 Presidents may be delayed until next month. Elsewhere, the Aussie also benefited from the encouraging trade news and a bulging trade surplus, but could not quite keep hold of the 0.6900 handle as its US counterpart built up a head of steam.

EUR/CHF/NZD/JPY

All overwhelmed by the Buck’s extended advances (index up over 98.200 at best), with single currency still heavy on approaches to 1.1100 and threatening to close below Fib support, while the Franc has slipped through 0.9950, Kiwi under 0.6350 and Yen below recent lows to test a Fib level protecting 109.50.

EM

In similar vein to yesterday, the Real is emerging as the regional underperformer, partly on the general and growing Dollar noted above, but also due to more Brazilian oil field auction angst as the 2nd batch of smaller sites failed to rouse any more interest, or arguably even less than the 4 that went under the hammer on Wednesday. Usd/Brl has been over 4.1000, but drifting back from peaks presently.

DOW

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced US and European regulators want documentation for its proposed 737 MAX software fix revised, which could delay the grounded jet’s return to service.
  • McDonald’s (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) New CEO purchased 500k shares.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class A (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is reportedly investigating its executives over inappropriate relationships and has hired a law. Elsewhere, it is in talks to change its political advertisement policy. (CNBC/WSJ)
  • Baidu Inc (BIDU) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 1.76 (exp. 1.25), Revenue 3.93bln (exp. 3.92bln). DAU’s +25% Y/Y at 189mln, sees Q4 revenue 3.78-4.02bln (Exp. 3.88bln)
  • Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) October Net Sales USD 11.92bln +6.8% Y/Y. Total company comparable sales +5.7%, e-commerce sales +16.5%.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) admitted to a further data leak, noting 100 developers accessed consumer data from Groups. (FB Director Blog Post)
  • Mastercard Inc. (MA) (Information Technology/IT Services) has partnered with a HK based wearable and digital payments provider, according to TappyTappy.
  • Qualcomm Inc. (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) Q3 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.78 (exp. 0.71), Revenue 4.8bln (exp. 4.7bln). Sees Q1 eps between 0.80-0.90 (Exp. 0.83), revenue 4.40-5.20bln (Exp. 4.86bln)
  • Wynn Resorts Ltd (WYNN) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 0.17 (exp. 0.94), Revenue 1.65bln (exp. 1.67bln). On track to launch a renovated West Casino at the Macau resort in late 2019.

BoE Governor Carney says pickup-up in UK growth likely to be limited by a lack of supply capacity in the economy
BoE Governor Carney says world risks slipping into low growth and low inflation rut, recent Brexit deal creates possibility of pickup in UK growth [COLLATED FEED]
content:
*BREXIT

  • New Brexit assumptions assumes the Brexit transition takes place over 3-years, vs. Prev. assumptions for a much longer transition
  • Pace of recover depends critically on how much Brexit uncertainty dissipates
  • Both reduced Brexit uncertainty and stronger world economy assumed in BoE forecast, but neither is assured
  • Notes, PM Johnsons Brexit agreement has significantly reduced risk of no-deal
  • As more details on post-Brexit talks appear, the BoE will adjust forecasts
  • Need to distinguish between January 31st Brexit deadline and when new trading arrangements take effect
  • “more realistic” assumptions about timing of Brexit transition party behind reduced growth forecasts - Deputy Governor Broadbent -

*DOMESTIC ECONOMY

  • Evidence that UK households are doing precautionary saving before Brexit
  • Pickup-up in UK growth likely to be limited by a lack of supply capacity in the economy
  • Risks to the UK’s growth are skewed to the downside
  • UK growth in future years is assisted by fiscal policy, stronger world and reduced uncertainty
  • Temporary factors are the biggest driver of expected short-term fall in UK inflation, we would look through temporary factors lowering inflation
  • If downside risks emerge to UK economy, there may be a need to provide reinforcement, but this is not pre-committing

*BOE POLICY

  • MPC has considerable policy flexibility and ammunition

*FISCAL POLICY

  • Fiscal policy an upside risk to UK growth outlook
  • Monetary policy can be more nimble than fiscal policy

*GLOBAL RATES

  • Headwinds from uncertainty are likely pushing down on global interest rates, exacerbating concerns on limited policy space

*GLOBAL GROWTH

  • Global growth is well below trend, are close to where we move to something that begins to feel like a recession
  • Questions whether some global supply chains are sustainable in light of the trade tension, all form of protectionism are more pervasive, persistent and damaging than prev. expected
  • We do not see the types of imbalances that are normally associated with global economy tipping into recession
  • On balance, we think world economy is stabilising

* GOVERNOR TENURE

  • Asked of he could stay on at BoE past January 31st, says he has committed to a smooth orderly transition
  • Will do what is necessary to ensure that there is appropriate handoff to successor
  • Given political pressures, no decision made on successor

subject: BoE Snap Analysis: Saunders and Haskel catch market off-side with a surprise cut
analysis_details: Policymakers at the MPC once again opted to stand pat on rates at 0.75%, however, this time around the decision was subject to dissent from Haskel and Saunders who, instead favoured a 25bps rate reduction (consensus looked for a unanimous decision). Haskel and Saunders opted to dissent on the basis that downside risks to the Bank’s projections have emanated from a softer global outlook and more persistent Brexit uncertainties affecting corporate and household spending. However, this stance was out-voted by the broader view that there is currently not enough data points available to assess the impact of the aforementioned concerns held by those wishing for a rate reduction. Elsewhere, one key aspect of the minutes release was the Bank’s updated view on Brexit which underpinned the accompanying projections in the MPR. Policymakers noted that as a result of the UK and EU striking a deal on the WA, Political declaration and extension to A50, the perceived likelihood of a no deal Brexit has fallen markedly. As such, the MPC now assume an orderly transition to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. With this in mind, the MPC opted to remove guidance on what action would be taken in the event of a no deal Brexit, whilst reiterating their mantra to respond in either direction to ensure “a sustainable return of inflation to the 2% target”. Furthermore, the Bank reassured markets once again that a period of “entrenched uncertainty” could be a cause to act, however, if these risks do not materialise and the economy recovers broadly in line with the MPC’s projections, “monetary policy could be tightened at a gradual pace and to a limited extent”. Overall, the latest communication from the Bank suggests less concern over the possibility of a no deal Brexit, given the increased clarity on the potential path for the UK and EU’s future trading relationship, however, a further prolongation of the Brexit process could see the BoE provide the UK economy with further monetary loosening. In terms of the MPC’s assessment of the UK economy as detailed in the accompanying Monetary Policy Report, the Banks messaging was somewhat muddled after opting to abandon direct comparisons for their quarterly projections with the August report given the dichotomy between market pricing and their assessment of the economy (market placed a lot more focus on the prospect of a no deal, whereas the Bank now does not envisage this). The Bank provided adjusted previous’ for quarterly projections, however, opted to not included any adjusted previous’ for the annual figures (to the bemusement of the journalists at the press conferences). As such, any comparison between the Banks view in November and August is difficult with the MPC trying to guide market expectations more towards the overall contents of the latest MPR rather than a contrast to the August QIR. In terms of what the November MPR tells us, the MPC expected UK GDP to pick up from 1.0% this year to 1.6% by the end of 2020, 1.8% in Q4 2021 and hit 2.1% by the end of the forecast period. The perceived trend of growth is predicated on the assumption of a reduction in uncertainty, albeit investment spending is held back by slower global growth. From an inflation perspective, inflation is seen as slipping to 1.4% by the end of the year and only modestly rising to 1.5% by the end of 2020 as a result of lower regulated energy and utility prices before picking up thereafter to target by the end of 2021 and 2.2% by the end of the forecast horizon. Piecing it all together, the dissent to the decision suggests that the MPC has moved further away from its previous bias of gradual and limited rate rises, however, the Bank feels confident in using PM Johnson’s deal as a basis for their forward-looking assumptions and therefore appear to have greater conviction in their outlook than in previous reports. That said, given the upcoming general election, whether or not this deal will materialise is yet to be seen and therefore by the time of the next MPR in January (on day before the current A50 extension deadline), it is plausible another Brexit outcome could have to be factored in. Overall, ING suggest “while we expect 2020 to be another uncertain year for the UK economy, we still think it is probably still a little too early to be pencilling in rate cuts”.

BoE November MPR Summary:
content:
Forecasts:

NOTE: The previous listed below have been adjusted by the MPC to reflect the changes in asset prices and the world outlook since the August report and are not those listed the August report. This was done on the basis that the August projections were based on the market view that a no deal Brexit was a possibility, whereas the MPC now, do not see this as much of a risk. A more detailed explanation can be seen on page 5 of the MPR.

CPI Inflation: 2019 Q4: 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%), 2020 Q4: 1.5% (Prev. 1.8%), 2021 Q4: 2.0% (Prev. 1.9%), 2022 Q4: 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%)

GDP Growth: 2019 Q4: 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%), 2020 Q4: 1.6% (Prev. 1.5%), 2021 Q4 1.8% (Prev. 2.2%), 2022 Q4 2.1% (Prev. 2.3%)

Note for the annual growth and average weekly earnings projections, these are the previous’ listed in the August report and the BoE have not provided adjusted previous’ like they have for the quarterly figures, as such they might not reflect the MPC’s view on the matter. The reason for the MPC not adjusting these previous’ is unclear.

GDP Growth (Annual): 2019: 1.25% (Prev. 1.3%), 2020: 1.25% (Prev. 1.3%), 2021: 1.75% (Prev. 2.3%)

Average Weekly Earnings: 2019: 3.5% (Prev. 3%), 2020: 3.25% (Prev. 3.25%), 2021: 3.75% (Prev. 4%)

Unemployment Rate: 2019 Q4: 3.9%, 2020 Q4: 4.0%, 2021 Q4 3.8%, 2022 Q4: 3.5%

Conditioning path for the Bank Rate implied by forward market interest rates:

2019 Q4: 0.7%, 2020 Q4: 0.5%, 2021 Q4 0.5%, 2022 Q4: 0.5%

Key judgement 1: Global GDP growth is projected to remain slow in the first part of the forecast period, partly reflecting the impact of trade protectionism, before rising gradually towards potential rates

Key judgement 2: Supply growth is subdued

Key judgement 3: Uncertainty is reduced by the Withdrawal Agreement

Key judgement 4: CPI inflation declines further below 2% in the near term before rising slightly above the target by the end of the forecast owing to building domestic price pressures

subject: BoE November Minutes Summary: MPC votes 7-2 (Exp. 9-0) in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% - Haskel and Saunders voted in favour of a 25bps cut
content:
Vote split on the base rate: MPC votes 7-2 to stand pat on rates at 0.75%

Vote split on corporate bonds: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln

Vote split on APF: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln

Rate guidance: Monetary policy could respond in either direction to changes in the economic outlook in order to ensure a sustainable return of inflation to the 2% target. If global growth fails to stabilise or Brexit uncertainties remain entrenched, monetary policy may need to reinforce the expected recovery in UK GDP growth and inflation. If these risks do not materialise and the economy recovers broadly in line with the MPC’s projections, monetary policy could be tightened at a gradual pace and to a limited extent. Note, the MPC have removed guidance on the event of a no-deal Brexit.

Brexit: As a result of the UK and EU striking a deal on the WA and Political declaration and extension to A50, the perceived likelihood of a no deal Brexit has fallen markedly.

Underlying assumptions of projections: Projections are based on the assumption of an orderly transition to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. The assumptions conclude no tariffs on UK-EU trade, whilst customs checks on UK-EU trade are introduced, some services trade would be subject to greater barriers, regulatory barriers with the EU are likely to gradually increase, the UK replicates a substantial proportion of EU trade agreements with non-EU countries. Full details can be found on Table 1, page 12 of the MPR.

Domestic growth: UK GDP has slowed materially this year and reflects weaker global growth, driven by trade protectionism and Brexit-related uncertainties. The agreements struck between the UK and EU are expected to remove some of the uncertainty facing businesses and households and as such, the MPC expects growth to pick up in 2020.

Inflation: Inflationary pressures are expected to lessen in the near term. Inflation is expected to fall to around 1.25% by the spring, owing to the temporary effect of falls in regulated energy and water prices. In the second half of the MPC’s forecast period, however, domestic inflationary pressures are expected to build before rising to slightly above 2% at the end of the forecast period.
reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction to the BoE’s dovish hold, which saw 2 members vote for a rate cut; Gilt Dec’ 19 futures shot higher to 131-73 from 131-32, before paring roughly half of the move. Cable meanwhile shot lower to 1.2810 from 128.55, before also paring much of the move.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are higher as risk sentiment derives support from the trade flow in early hours
  • China and US have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, MOFCOM said; noting the magnitude of tariff cancellations for Phase 1 can be negotiated if a deal is reached
  • Debt complex is significantly subdued on the risk-on tone, USD/CNH drops further below the 7.0 mark
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Initial Jobless Claims and Consumer Credit, BoE Rate Decision, MPR & Press Conference with Governor Carney, Riksbank’s Skingsley, Fed’s Kaplan, ECB’s Lagarde, supply from the US
  • Earnings: Walt Disney, Booking Holdings, Zoetis, Air Products and Chemical, Activision Blizzard, Johnson Controls International, Monster Beverage, Fox Corp

TRADE

China and US have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, China's Commerce Ministry says, adds that the magnitude of tariff cancellations for Phase 1 deal can be negotiated, If a Phase 1 trade deal is reached, both sides must cancel tariffs at the same time with the proportion based on agreement. (Newswires)

A senior Chinese diplomat said a presidential meeting appeared “extremely important” for US President Trump but Beijing did not see it as critical, according to a source cited by an updated SCMP article, "The Chinese diplomat also said Beijing felt that Trump was fixated on a “phase one” deal for domestic political purposes, according to the source.". (SCMP)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisively as they initially took their cue from the similar performance of their US peers; though strengthened on the later optimistic trade reports regarding the cancellation of tariffs. ASX 200 (+1.0%) was underpinned by outperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector with shares in NAB lifted despite a decline in full year profits, as the big 4 bank maintained its dividend unchanged from the interim and also announced top level executives will not receive short-term bonuses this year. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was pressured by a firmer currency and amid a slew of earnings including SoftBank which posted its first quarterly operating loss in 14 years due to the WeWork fiasco, while Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) were choppy amid a lack of clarity on the timing and location for the signing of the US-China phase 1 trade deal and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again, with gaming stocks also pressured after Galaxy Entertainment and Wynn Macau posted softer revenue figures. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly subdued following the recent downturn in prices and amid the lack of BoJ buying today, but with downside stemmed by the inconclusive risk tone and support ahead of the 153.00 level.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0008 vs. Exp. 7.0044 (Prev. 7.0080)

Falling corporate profits in China are said to flash a warning sign of a deepening economic slowdown and easier credit can only do so much to support growth as bad loans have already reached alarming level at some lenders, according to an article. (Nikkei)

China reportedly to consider a wave of bank mergers, in order to bolster stability; Problematic banks with under USD 14bln in assets would reportely be urged to merge/restructure under a potential plan being determined by financial regulators, accordin to sources. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

South Korea and the US are reportedly to undertake joint air exercises this month as scheduled, in-spite of complaints via North Korea., Yonhap citing sources. (Yonhap)

Rate of uranium enrichment at Iran's Fordow facility is almost at pre-nuclear levels, Arab News. (Twitter)

 

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%) are modestly firmer following positive trade developments on the US/China trade front, with headlines suggesting that China and the US had agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, if they reach a Phase One deal, although further details are for now scant. “as for how much will be eliminated, we will consider the agreement reached in Phase One”, China’s MOFCOM stated. Looking at indices, Germany’s DAX moved as high as 13290, its best levels since early February 2018, while Euro Stoxx 50 came within a whisker of its 2017 high at 3710. Sectors performance is reflective of the markets risk-on feel; defensives lag (Utilities -0.5%, Health Care unch., Staples -0.3%) while the more risk sensitive Tech (+0.3%), Consumer Discretionary (+1.0%), Industrials and Materials (+0.6%) lead the pack. Meanwhile, the Energy (-0.4%) sector has struggled to take advantage of the market rally, weighed on by crude prices which fell substantially yesterday, albeit the sector and energy complex have recoiled off lows amid the aforementioned trade headlines. In terms of individual movers, things are still very much dominated by earnings: Vestas Wind systems (+11.6%) post-earnings and in light of the announcement of a EUR 200mln buyback programme. Lufthansa (+8.1%) rose to the top of its index despite strike threats after earnings topped analyst forecasts with heavy-weight Siemens (+4.6%) a close second following encouraging earnings coupled with a EUR 0.10/shr dividend raise. Other post-earning movers include: UniCredit (+5.9%), ProsiebentSat1 (-5.0%), Scout24 (-4.3%), Commerzbank (+0.3%) and Deutsche Telekom (-2.9%)

UniCredit (UCG IM) CEO says the ECB is also open to giving green light to further buy backs if banks have strong enough capital. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and the Green Party have formed an electoral pact, details to be announced Thursday; reports indicate the pact will cover between 60-70 constituencies, specifically, 49 seats in England and 11 in Wales. (BBC/Guardian)

European Commission Economic Forecasts: cuts 2019 EZ GDP growth forecast to 1.1% (Prev. 1.2%) and 2020 GDP growth forecast to 1.2% (Prev. 1.4%)

- German 2019 GDP cut to 0.4% (prev 0.5%); 2020 1.0% (prev 1.4%)

- Italy 2019 GDP cut to 0.1% (prev 0.1%); 2020 0.4% (prev 0.7%)

- Expects Frances budget deficit to rise to 3.1%, above the EU ceiling, sees drop to 2.2% in 2020

- Expects German budget surplus at 1.2% this year and 0.6% in 2020

ECB's Holzmann (Hawk) says negative rates currently send the wrong signal, ECB should get rid of them as soon as possible. (Newswires)

 

FX

YUAN - The Cnh and Cny have both been boosted by latest comments from China’s MOFCOM claiming that Beijing and Washington have now agreed to lift tit-for-tat import levies in tandem and step-by-step once Phase 1 of the overall deal is agreed. The offshore and onshore Yuan are back above the psychological 7.0000 mark and extending gains towards key technical resistance around 6.9625 for the former vs the Usd after retreating on Wednesday and pulling back further when reports about a delay to December from this month for the Trump-Xi meeting to sign part one of the pact broke.

 

AUD/NZD - The main beneficiaries of the more positive China-US trade talk, with the Aussie back on the 0.6900 handle and Aud/Usd also boosted by much wider Australian trade surplus, while the Kiwi has bounced firmly from circa 0.6350 towards 0.6400 vs the Greenback, but lagging its Antipodean peer as the Aud/Nzd cross rebounds from around 1.0800 to 1.0825+.

EUR/CAD/GBP - Also firmer against the Buck, as the DXY dips a bit further from another 98.000+ venture that topped out just short of Fib resistance again, with the single currency also spurred on by hawkish ECB rhetoric via Holzmann and back above a key chart support level within a 1.1055-92 range. The Loonie has pared post-Canadian Ivey PMI declines from almost 1.3200 to probe bids/support ahead of 1.3150 and Cable has bounced off the 21 DMA (1.2839) through 1.2850 and not far from the 10 DMA (1.2881) in the run up to the BoE from high noon.

CHF/JPY - Narrowly mixed and hampered by another reversal in sentiment/positioning in favour riskier currencies and assets, as the Franc retreats below 0.9900 vs the Dollar and Yen reverses from 108.66 to 109.19.

SEK/NOK/EM - In stark contrast to the above, renewed risk appetite has propelled the Scandi Crowns to revisit recent and/or register fresh peaks, with Eur/Sek having another look under 10.6500 and Eur/Nok breaching 10.1000 to expose the next major downside chart level at 10.0610 following stronger than forecast Norwegian manufacturing output. Elsewhere, most Emerging Market currencies are getting carried by the revived US-China trade narrative, but the Lira is lagging on deteriorating US-Turkish relations and increasingly dovish CBRT expectations.

 

Australian Trade Balance G&S (AUD)(Sep) 7.2B vs. Exp. 5.0B (Prev. 5.9B, Rev. 6.6B). (Newswires) Australian Exports (Sep) 3% (Prev. -3.0%) Australian Imports (Sep) 3% (Prev. 0.0%)

 

FIXED INCOME

Although Chinese contentions appearing to confirm conditional agreement on the removal of tariffs have not been corroborated by the US, debt markets seem to be taking silence or the lack of any denial as validation on the basis that no news may well be good. Indeed, Bunds have now taken out Wednesday’s Eurex low, 170.00 and support just below the bog figure on the way down to 169.83, while Gilts have nudged nearer to 131.00 at 131.15 and the 10 year T-note hit 128-22+, with the yield up through recent peaks and well over yesterday’s auction level. Ahead, jobless claims and the long bond sale that comes with an even bigger concession.

 

COMMODITIES 

Crude markets are staging a recovery, with positive developments on the US/China trade front (US & China agreeing to roll back existing tariffs) acting as a tailwind. However, WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 2020 futures are still well off of yesterday’s USD 57.83/bbl and USD 63.30/bbl highs, after the complex was hit by a bearish EIA crude inventory report and concerns about a delay to the signing of the US/China Phase 1 trade deal - WTI is now consolidating just shy of the USD 57.00/bbl handle, Brent just beneath yesterday’s pre-EIA Inventory data lows at USD 62.39/bbl, which is acting as resistance. In terms of the metals; Gold price were hit by haven outflows on the back of positive trade related developments, falling to lows of USD 1486/oz from above USD 1490/oz. Copper, meanwhile, was buoyed and managed to reclaim the USD 2.700/lbs level.

Saudi Aramco signs 2020 crude oil supply at China's largest trade fair; agreements made with five customers, increasing total volume by 151k BPD compared to 2019 supply contracts, according to a statement. (Newswires)

Crude markets are staging a recovery, with positive developments on the US/China trade front (US & China agreeing to roll back existing tariffs) acting as a tailwind. However, WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 2020 futures are still well off of yesterday’s USD 57.83/bbl and USD 63.30/bbl highs, after the complex was hit by a bearish EIA crude inventory report and concerns about a delay to the signing of the US/China Phase 1 trade deal - WTI is now consolidating just shy of the USD 57.00/bbl handle, Brent just beneath yesterday’s pre-EIA Inventory data lows at USD 62.39/bbl, which is acting as resistance. In terms of the metals; Gold price were hit by haven outflows on the back of positive trade related developments, falling to lows of USD 1486/oz from above USD 1490/oz. Copper, meanwhile, was buoyed and managed to reclaim the USD 2.700/lbs level.

subject: Fixed Income: brief respite before bears pounce on bonds again
content: Although Chinese contentions appearing to confirm conditional agreement on the removal of tariffs have not been corroborated by the US, debt markets seem to be taking silence or the lack of any denial as validation on the basis that no news may well be good. Indeed, Bunds have now taken out Wednesday’s Eurex low, 170.00 and support just below the bog figure on the way down to 169.83, while Gilts have nudged nearer to 131.00 at 131.15 and the 10 year T-note hit 128-22+, with the yield up through recent peaks and well over yesterday’s auction level. Ahead, jobless claims and the long bond sale that comes with an even bigger concession.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Renminbi rallies on US-China tariff reciprocity reports
content:
YUAN

The Cnh and Cny have both been boosted by latest comments from China’s MOFCOM claiming that Beijing and Washington have now agreed to lift tit-for-tat import levies in tandem and step-by-step once Phase 1 of the overall deal is agreed. The offshore and onshore Yuan are back above the psychological 7.0000 mark and extending gains towards key technical resistance around 6.9625 for the former vs the Usd after retreating on Wednesday and pulling back further when reports about a delay to December from this month for the Trump-Xi meeting to sign part one of the pact broke.

AUD/NZD 

The main beneficiaries of the more positive China-US trade talk, with the Aussie back on the 0.6900 handle and Aud/Usd also boosted by much wider Australian trade surplus, while the Kiwi has bounced firmly from circa 0.6350 towards 0.6400 vs the Greenback, but lagging its Antipodean peer as the Aud/Nzd cross rebounds from around 1.0800 to 1.0825+.

EUR/CAD/GBP

Also firmer against the Buck, as the DXY dips a bit further from another 98.000+ venture that topped out just short of Fib resistance again, with the single currency also spurred on by hawkish ECB rhetoric via Holzmann and back above a key chart support level within a 1.1055-92 range. The Loonie has pared post-Canadian Ivey PMI declines from almost 1.3200 to probe bids/support ahead of 1.3150 and Cable has bounced off the 21 DMA (1.2839) through 1.2850 and not far from the 10 DMA (1.2881) in the run up to the BoE from high noon.

CHF/JPY 

Narrowly mixed and hampered by another reversal in sentiment/positioning in favour riskier currencies and assets, as the Franc retreats below 0.9900 vs the Dollar and Yen reverses from 108.66 to 109.19.

SEK/NOK/EM

In stark contrast to the above, renewed risk appetite has propelled the Scandi Crowns to revisit recent and/or register fresh peaks, with Eur/Sek having another look under 10.6500 and Eur/Nok breaching 10.1000 to expose the next major downside chart level at 10.0610 following stronger than forecast Norwegian manufacturing output. Elsewhere, most Emerging Market currencies are getting carried by the revived US-China trade narrative, but the Lira is lagging on deteriorating US-Turkish relations and increasingly dovish CBRT expectations.

content:
• The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook remain on the downside
  • Incoming information since the last Governing Council meeting in early September confirms the previous assessment of a protracted weakness in euro area growth dynamics, the persistence of prominent downside risks and muted inflation pressures
  • Combining the outcome of the economic analysis with the signals coming from the monetary analysis, the Governing Council confirmed that an ample degree of monetary accommodation is still necessary for the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term

subject: UK debt and STIR futures choppy from the off on BoE day
content: The latest house price survey has been taken in stride, as widely expected, but Gilts and Short Sterling contracts have been buffeted in early Liffe trade by the latest US-China trade updates per MOFCOM that have offset much of the disappointment caused by reports that Trump and Xi may not meet to sign off on Phase 1 of the trade accord until December instead of this month. The 10 year debt future has regained composure within a 131.69-52 range vs yesterday’s 131.62 close and is holding up better than Bunds and US Treasuries (former still sub-parity, albeit only 5 ticks adrift compared to -29 ticks at one stage), as attention shifts to the MPC policy decisions, minutes and November MPR, all at midday, then BoE Governor Carney’s press conference 30 minutes later – see the Ransquawk Research Suite for a full ‘super Thursday’ preview. Back to Liffe, the 3 month strip is flat to 1 tick down on the day vs -0.5 to -2 ticks at worst.

content: The 10 year German benchmark has been knocked off the recovery ladder by breaking headlines suggesting that China and the US have agreed to a staged and simultaneous removal of tariffs according to content and on the premise that each phase of the trade accord are concluded. Bunds got to within 3 ticks of 171.00 in early Eurex trade and were in the process of retesting highs in wake of weaker than forecast German ip data before the Chinese Commerce Ministry reports hit the wires and dragged the core Eurozone bond down to 170.38 alongside US Treasuries. However, the selling has subsequently abated ahead of Germany’s construction PMI, the ECB monthly bulletin and EC forecasts, plus heavy Spanish and French supply.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

7th November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as they took their cue from the similar performance of their US peers and with sentiment clouded by trade uncertainty after reports suggested the signing of the US-China phase 1 deal could be pushed back to December. ASX 200 (+1.0%) was underpinned by outperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector with shares in NAB lifted despite a decline in full year profits, as the big 4 bank maintained its dividend unchanged from the interim and also announced top level executives will not receive short-term bonuses this year. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was pressured by a firmer currency and amid a slew of earnings including SoftBank which posted its first quarterly operating loss in 14 years due to the WeWork fiasco, while Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were choppy amid a lack of clarity on the timing and location for the signing of the US-China phase 1 trade deal and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again, with gaming stocks also pressured after Galaxy Entertainment and Wynn Macau posted softer revenue figures.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 7th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded indecisively as they took their cue from the similar performance of their US peers
  • US President Trump meeting with Chinese President Xi to sign a trade deal could be delayed until December as discussions over terms and venue continue
  • Senior US administration official said that the US is mulling a Trump-Xi meeting to sign an interim trade deal after the NATO summit in London in early December (3rd-4th)
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Output, Chinese FX Reserves, US Initial Jobless Claims and Consumer Credit, BoE Rate Decision, MPR & Press Conference with Governor Carney, Riksbank’s Skingsley, Fed’s Kaplan, ECB’s Lagarde, supply from the US and France
  • Earnings: Walt Disney, Booking Holdings, Zoetis, Air Products and Chemical, Activision Blizzard, Johnson Controls International, Monster Beverage, Fox Corp, Siemens, Deutsche Telekom, Zurich Insurance, Siemens Healthineers, Generali, UniCredit, Vestas Wind Systems, ArcelorMittal, HeidelbergCement, Telecom Italia, Lufthansa, Leonardo, Rheinmetall

7th November 2019 

·        Asian equity markets traded indecisively as they took their cue from the similar performance of their US peers

·        US President Trump meeting with Chinese President Xi to sign a trade deal could be delayed until December as discussions over terms and venue continue

·        Senior US administration official said that the US is mulling a Trump-Xi meeting to sign an interim trade deal after the NATO summit in London in early December (3rd-4th)

·        Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Output, Chinese FX Reserves, US Initial Jobless Claims and Consumer Credit, BoE Rate Decision, MPR & Press Conference with Governor Carney, Riksbank’s Skingsley, Fed’s Kaplan, ECB’s Lagarde, supply from the US and France

·        Earnings: Walt Disney, Booking Holdings, Zoetis, Air Products and Chemical, Activision Blizzard, Johnson Controls International, Monster Beverage, Fox Corp, Siemens, Deutsche Telekom, Zurich Insurance, Siemens Healthineers, Generali, UniCredit, Vestas Wind Systems, ArcelorMittal, HeidelbergCement, Telecom Italia, Lufthansa, Leonardo, Rheinmetall

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisively as they took their cue from the similar performance of their US peers and with sentiment clouded by trade uncertainty after reports suggested the signing of the US-China phase 1 deal could be pushed back to December. ASX 200 (+1.0%) was underpinned by outperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector with shares in NAB lifted despite a decline in full year profits, as the big 4 bank maintained its dividend unchanged from the interim and also announced top level executives will not receive short-term bonuses this year. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was pressured by a firmer currency and amid a slew of earnings including SoftBank which posted its first quarterly operating loss in 14 years due to the WeWork fiasco, while Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were choppy amid a lack of clarity on the timing and location for the signing of the US-China phase 1 trade deal and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again, with gaming stocks also pressured after Galaxy Entertainment and Wynn Macau posted softer revenue figures. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly subdued following the recent downturn in prices and amid the lack of BoJ buying today, but with downside stemmed by the inconclusive risk tone and support ahead of the 153.00 level.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0008 vs. Exp. 7.0044 (Prev. 7.0080)

US President Trump meeting with Chinese President Xi to sign a trade deal could be delayed until December as discussions over terms and venue continue, while it is still possible a deal may not be reached although a deal is more likely than not according to a US official. The official added that China pushing for more tariff rollbacks is not seen as derailing the progress and that Europe is seen as a likely venue for a Trump-Xi meeting with Switzerland and Sweden among possible choices, while Iowa is not likely.

Senior US administration official said that the US is mulling a Trump-Xi meeting to sign an interim trade deal after the NATO summit in London in early December, but no decision has been made yet. US is said to have asked for Chinese President Xi Jinping's travel schedule to see where and when a possible phase one deal could be signed. (Newswires/Fox/Twitter)

Falling corporate profits in China are said to flash a warning sign of a deepening economic slowdown and easier credit can only do so much to support growth as bad loans have already reached alarming level at some lenders, according to an article. (Nikkei)

UK/EU

Latest Sky News/YouGov poll: Conservative: 36% (Prev. 38%), Labour 25% (Prev. 25%), Lib Dems 17% (Prev. 16%), Brexit Party 11% (Prev. 11%), Green Party 5% (Prev. 5%), SNP 4% (Prev. 4%), Plaid Cymru 1% (Prev. 1%). (Sky News)

Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and the Green Party have formed an electoral pact, details to be announced Thursday; reports indicate the pact will cover between 60-70 constituencies, specifically, 49 seats in England and 11 in Wales. (BBC/Guardian)

EU Trade Commissioner Malmstrom said the US is still not ready for talks on industry duty reactions and that the EU still faces threat of US auto tariffs, while she reiterated that the EU would retaliate against any US tariffs. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, a sturdy greenback remained the state of play in which the DXY tested the 98.00 level as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD extended on this week’s lows around the mid-1.1000 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Nonetheless, overnight price action, as well as pertinent news flow was relatively light for the greenback and its transatlantic peers. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was subdued by the vague risk tone and with the flows into the Japanese currency facilitated by rising JGB yields, while antipodeans have ceded further ground against USD which coincided with a weaker CNY as the trade uncertainty overshadowed a firmer reference rate setting.

Australian Trade Balance G&S (AUD)(Sep) 7.2B vs. Exp. 5.0B (Prev. 5.9B, Rev. 6.6B). (Newswires) Australian Exports (Sep) 3% (Prev. -3.0%) Australian Imports (Sep) 3% (Prev. 0.0%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued in which WTI crude futures languished firmly below the USD 57.00/bbl after the losses seen in the prior session where oil slipped around 2% in the aftermath of a bearish EIA crude inventory report, while the ongoing trade-related uncertainty has also hampered any recovery for energy prices. Elsewhere, gold traded sideways throughout the session below the USD 1500/oz level with the precious metal restricted by a robust USD, and copper conformed to the dreary performance across the complex due to the indecisiveness across overnight markets.

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea called upcoming US military exercises extremely provocative and a dangerous act, while it added that dialogue with the US is on the verge of extinction, according to BNO News. (Twitter)

 

Turkish officials said President Erdogan and US President Trump spoke on the phone and reconfirmed they will meet in Washington on November 13th. (Newswires)

US

 

After this week’s sharp rise in yields, the Treasury curve bull-flattened on Wednesday, though major spreads only narrowed modestly. An early dip after better than expected Germany factory orders was short-lived, and the complex continued to rally amid caution on US/China trade talks, where there are still some concerns that the deal might fall apart. A solid 10-year auction added to the rally, after the sale stopped through the screens by 1bps (recently, the auctions have tailed frequently), with cover above recent averages, and indirect bidder participation picking up – the well-received auction reveals that there is still demand for medium-dated US paper, and as such, providing validation to the analysts who have this week talked about how the complex has run out of fresh reasons for yields to continue rising; this view was encapsulated by a hefty trade in the TYZ9 131-00 strike (which analysts said looks for an implied 10-year yield of 1.6% vs the current 1.82%), where paper paid 3 ticks 100k times (50k on the screens, 50k blocked). T-note futures (Z9) settled up 13 ticks at 129.10+.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades indecisive after reports suggested the signing of the US-China phase 1 deal could be pushed back to December
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive as they take their cue from the similar performance of their US peers and with sentiment clouded by trade uncertainty after reports suggested the signing of the US-China phase 1 deal could be pushed back to December. ASX 200 (+0.7%) is underpinned by outperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector as shares in NAB gain despite reporting a decline in profits, as the big 4 bank maintained its dividend unchanged from the interim and also announced top level executives will not receive short-term bonuses this year. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) is pressured by a firmer currency and amid a slew of earnings including SoftBank which posted its first quarterly operating loss in 14 years due to the WeWork fiasco, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) are choppy amid a lack of clarity on the timing and location for the signing of the US-China phase 1 trade deal and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again, with gaming stocks also pressured after Galaxy Entertainment and Wynn Macau posted softer revenue figures.

In FX markets, a steadfast greenback remains the state of play with the DXY consolidating just slightly off the 98.00 level as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD retest this week’s lows around the mid-1.1000 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Nonetheless, overnight price action, as well as pertinent news flow has been light for the greenback and its transatlantic peers although a major newswire poll recently showed around two-thirds of analysts anticipate the USD-rally to continue for another 6-months, while the same poll also predicts EUR/USD to reclaim 1.1400 in a year. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is subdued by the vague risk tone and with the flows into Japanese currency facilitated by rising JGB yields, while antipodeans have ceded further ground against USD which coincides with a weaker CNY as the trade uncertainty overshadows a firmer reference rate setting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are slightly lower in a continuation in the recent downturn in prices and amid the lack of BoJ buying today, but with downside stemmed by the inconclusive risk tone and by support ahead of the 153.00 level.
